content.description: A stem chimney  through 90 feet of very solid rock in the giant butt crack of John Holmes. Climb the first twelve feet and stand on a chocked boulder. Chimney your way up the thinner outer lip of the feature to a crows nest.  It widens after the nest and eventually angles left to the chains.  The climbing is very unique for a sport route and is not grovely at all. There are 100 ways to climb this route but I highly recommend that you face out whenever you can to maximize the exposure and to enjoy the view.   The route stays in the shade almost all day.
content.location: In the wide 5 foot chimney on the backside of the detachment.  It is a very obvious feature.

content.description:
5.8 or 5.10c

.   A short but fantastic jug haul through steep rock gets you to the first set of chains. Highly recommended!   You can continue on past the shaft and through the sharp overhanging scrotum of the John Holmes Member @ 10c if you so desire.
content.location: Very obvious pocketed, phallic, twig and berries pillar.

content.description: Easy low angle climbing for the first 20 feet.  Go to the right and step off of the rounded areteish feature using good jugs on the inside of the feature. Work left through steep but positive holds and traverse through the crux of the climb on thin edges to gain the crack. Enjoy a few handjams to get to easier terrain and the chains.
content.location: Use the trail at the base of the Hammer Wall to gain the upper tier.  Look for the obvious phallic feature of the pillar. This route is not actually on the detachment but is on the same wall as the Hammer Wall.

content.description: It looks to be very well protected and looks like it is on nicely varnished rock.  From the ground it looks like a fun route. I have not climbed it yet.
content.location: On the nice orange rock just right of the big white scoop and just around the corner from the very obvious pocketed pillar.
